Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I feel like I didn't really learn anything from this course aside from the fact that I don't like anthropology.

I gained so much knowledge and insight from this class. I learned that I actually really love anthropology and might even consider getting a PhD in anthropology in the future. I also developed great insight into how biology, culture, and social understanding could all come together in both life and a class. I absolutely loved this class.

I learned a lot about human evolution and how our biological processes evolved. We learned about human evolution in the context of stress, sleep, reproduction, diet, medicine, and disease. The information was very interesting to learn even as a non-STEM/non-anthro major. We also learned how to read and analyze research papers.
Learn about the subject matter and get practice looking at empirical studies in section.
I gained knowledge in evolutionary biology concepts.
Learned about evolutionary biology from basic biological functions to deeper concepts on how we should think about disease/medicine and how to incorporate social and cultural factors into science
Knowledge of certain biological processes, frameworks in human evolutionary biology for understanding disparate phenomena (esp. diseases), experimental design in anthropology and public health
Learned about evolutionary biology and how to interpret graphs
Epigenetics, life-history theory, reproduction theories, mensuration cycles, and conceptions of race

I learned about a variety of concepts related to human evolutionary biology, from scientific topics like cell division to social and cultural hypotheses. I learned how to read and analyze scientific papers, and connect a variety of subjects through reading responses.
applicable content about the human experience.

I learned about anthropology and the intertwining of biology and culture. I learned how to read and discuss scientific papers. I learned about important biological concepts behind topics such as sleep, stress, and reproduction.

I learned a lot of information about a vast array of concepts, from stress to the biological basis of life to life history theory. The class taught how to read a scientific study more critically, how to apply scientific/anthropological concepts to pop culture and sensationalist media. It taught me how to be a more critical thinker, especially in relation to science.
I learned the basics of life history and evolutionary biology.
I learned a lot about how humans have evolved into the beings we are today, and how we compare to other mammals. It was interesting to learn about who we are and how we came to be.

I learned so much about why human development followed the path that it did with evolutionary traits it maintained. I thought that the class was beyond interesting with real-world implications regarding stress, diet, and exercise, and the professor is an absolute dream.
Great understanding of human evolutionary biology and the scientific reasoning to it
I learned how to understand my body better and analyze not only biological signs but cultural and social signs when assessing the causes and consequences of human behavior.
I learned an incredible range of information about the human species in relation to evolutionary thinking.
Basic understanding of biology facts.
I learned some fun folk knowledge and in general questionable facts
I learned about the biology of human evolution.

I thought it was a stellar course marketed towards non-science majors. I learned a lot of basic information about humans which, being a human myself, was useful. Valeggia is brilliant, kind, and sensitivegenuinely cares about her students, which is rarer than it should beand almost worth taking a science course to get a chance to know. TAs varied a lot in their level of expertise but overall were good.

I learned to read scientific papers and understand the world, my body, and human life in completely new ways. This class changed how I understand and move through the world way more than I thought it would.

Gained a solid overview of evolutionary theory, life history theory, and a bit of biology and anatomy. I also took Prof. Valeggia's Fall course on women's reproductive biology so I refreshed some of the concepts from that. I now feel pretty comfortable discussing evolution and life history trade offs.

I learned about human evolution from a life history perspective, which is something that I was not familiar with prior to taking this course. I learned that almost all human traits were adaptive at some point, but recent changes in our environment have given rise to evolutionary mismatches -- for instance, increased incidence of obesity and immuno-regulatory disorders.
I learned a lot about humanity and how we have evolved along with our environment.
Learned a lot more about what it means to be human. Lots of insight that puts life in perspective to the greater world.
I learned how to read scientific papers and discuss important evolutionary topics.
I learned how evolution has shaped us and what that means for how our minds and bodies function. The course gave me a better understanding of why we are the way we are.
I developed a greater understanding and appreciation for various biological processes, and how evolution and changing environments impact human growth and health.
I learned so much
Helped me develop a broader understanding of how biology interacts with our sociocultural surroundings.
This was my first science class at Yale. I learned how life history influences evolutionary biology and how to think critically about biological processes.

The class title gives it away: I learned human evolutionary biology and life history. This included studying epigenetics, stress and stress responses, human diversity, human energetics, human growth, and human reproductive biology, just to name a few topics from the class. I learned how to think about human evolution through an anthropological lens.
I learned a lot in this course about the evolutionary mechanisms by which humans have formed into our modern-day forms.

This was the first anthropology class I've ever taken, and I feel like, in some ways, I gained a worldview. Generally speaking, I learned how to view human evolution through a life history lens (particularly through the concept of trade-offs). Pretty much everything in the course comes back to this, and I often found myself learning things that then made a lot of things I'd observed out in the world make sense.

This is a course that will make you relate everything you know about the human body to evolution in relation to systems of power. The first half of the semester begins with specific bodily functions: transcription, translation, etc. The second half of the semester zooms out to look more at human evolution as it intersects with culture. In every lesson, the information was traced back to cultural implications, biases, privilege, etc. so that students can begin to understand that science, just like anything, is a product of a hierarchical world. Also in this way, students are asked to draw connections to many things they see in every day life. Therefore, the information in this class feels incredibly applicable to the real world, making it the perfect class for non-STEM people like myself.

I learned a lot about human evolutionary processes and about the principles of life history. I also learned a significant amount about biological anthropology as a field, as well as the importance of applying ideals outside of western/industrialized mindsets when doing anthropological studies.

Wow I learned so much: understanding human life history from an evolutionary standpoint, the evolutionary explanation for some diseases we have today, evolutionary explanations for just about everything from race, sex, reproduction, energy use and intake, and more!
I learned a new way to look at medicine and science.
I learned a lot about human evolutionary past, and how humans evolved to be the way they are today.
Learned more about the human body, human variation, and evolution.
Not much honestly. Very boring class with little interesting material. Lots of trivia strung together
Learned a lot of good, general knowledge about the body and its systems, very applicable to life/useful.
It was great for thinking about scientific and public health news.
Learned about evolutionary processes as well as adaptations that have made humans unique amongst our close great ape relatives.
Basic understanding of human evolution from an anthropological perspective

Introduction to the effect of evolution on human anatomy, lifestyle and behavior
Focus on reproductive ecology
Exploration of human diversity

First, I learned that evolution impacts so many aspects of my daily life that I never previously thought twice about, from stress to sleep patterns to eating habits. This course also helped me develop an ability to consider the "big picture" when studying or taking a test: instead of simply memorizing many minute details, we were encouraged to synthesize our knowledge and apply it to difficult questions. Finally, I learned that for every human phenomenon, there are usually many explanations, sometimes based in evolution and sometimes not. I learned to critically evaluate "paradoxes" or improbable situations and consider all the possible factors that could have led to their development in humans.
I learned some facts about human evolution, metabolism, and health.
I learned how to critically think about evolutionary concepts and how to connect common themes across topics. This course also helped me learn how to most effectively read scientific articles.

I think i got a good overview of human evolutionary and life history theory. The course gave us a good framework for understanding human reproductive history and biology, epidemiology, and human life history.

I gained an overview of the field of human evolutionary biology, as the name of the course suggests. Essentially, I learned why certain human traits are evolutionary advantageous. Even as an English major, I found all 13 weeks of the course exciting, engaging, and relevant to my field of study. Highlights included examining race from the perspective of biological anthropology (which we conclude is not a scientific category), as well as the paleo-diet and paleo-sleep patterns. It was engaging and extremely well-taught.
learned about different topics about human evolutionary biology and life history, how to read scientific articles (read one every week in section)

Strengths: Professor Valeggia is incredibly kind and clearly cares a lot about her students, the assignments are all fair, discussion section doesn't require a ton of prep work in terms of reading

Weaknesses: I felt like some of the things said in this class weren't exactly biologically accurate based on what I'd learned in some of my other classes, so I always found myself taking things with a grain of salt.
It can be very boring at times if you're not fully engaged. There are a lot of readings, but it's possible to get by without reading them.

The strengths of this course are both the material covered and the teacher. Both contribute to a very positive learning environment where a diverse array of information and opinions are shared. I also LOVE the 5-minute meditations at the beginning of every class. They're very cathartic. I can't think of any weaknesses of this course.

This course is very much geared towards non-science majors. With that being said, I think sometimes Professor Valeggia is confusing and the actual structure of the course is not the most intuitive at times.

Strengths: meditation before class helped me focus for the rest of lecture. Interesting information that was easy to learn. Good preparation for exams.
Weaknesses: Lack of variety in assignments; they were only readings and reading questions. Maybe it could be spiced up with some interesting projects or fun interactive activities.
Connected material to real world and our lives pretty well.

I think the material in the course had the potential to be very interesting. However, I found the lectures very dry and overall pretty uninteresting. It was difficult to really pay attention and the weekly topics were all so different. It would have been better if there was a more cohesive structure. Moreover, the grading in this class is very subjective. Everything is based on two tests and the discussion questions. Anything covered in class could show up on the exam, and I never felt like the exam truly captured how much I learned. Furthermore, the grading on the exams could be so subjective because everything is essay-based. Overall, I felt like this class did not intellectually stimulate me at all. There was so much rote memorization.
Interesting material, interesting lectures.  Section could be better run.
useful slides, fair exams, good section discussions

Strength: a good mix of classic biology in the beginning with a bit more social science theories in the second half of the course.
Weaknesses: In presenting various theories, Professor Valeggia had a clear preference. In lectures, weekly assignments, and exams, the liberal interpretation was always the right answer. It felt that political ideologies affected her teaching (and I agree with most of her stances, but I still felt this way).

I thought this course was very engaging and well-planned. I really enjoyed Professor Valeggia's 5 minutes of meditation at the beginning of each class, and I thought the material was always presented in a very understandable way. I think there needs to be more consistency across different sections, because it seems like some sections talked about certain topics a lot more than others, but we were all tested on the same things.
meditation is fun! lectures are interesting but sometimes move a little slow

I really enjoyed the day we went to the TEAL and had to brainstorm our own study as it allowed us to apply the skills we learned in lecture. I wish we had more days with interactive activities like that. The lectures sometimes were repetitive and slow, but it was never too bad.

I think this course was strong in that the material was captivating and never too abstract. As a non-science major, the topics were digestible.

There is a lot of reading for this course that isn't really helpful or relevant, so I think the reading should be narrowed to what is really relevant to class material. Section was sometimes just a repeat of the readings we did and could have been more engaging, but on the whole not too bad.

Strengths:
Meditating before every class! Claudia is a phenomenal teacher and person; taking the class just for her would be a smart move. The assignments were very fair, and the two exams were likewise extremely doable while still requiring legitimate learning on the part of the student. 

Weaknesses:
Not many! Sometimes certain weeks would be very heavy on readings, but other than that this was a great class.
It covers the basics of a whole range of concepts, which is ideal for a science course.
One strength of this course was most of the material was easy to follow. One weakness is that the tests sometimes put an emphasis on hardly covered topics.

I think the topics are fascinating and Professor Valeggia is a fantastic lecturer. I think that the course is well defined and follows a good structure, but that sometimes sections feel awkward and not nearly as engaging as the lectures.

Strengths: Professor Valeggia is amazing

Weakness: TAs are really nice but don't really master the subjects
It was a very strong course. I really enjoyed Professor Valeggias lecture style as well as my section.
Weird progression of lectures and one very rude TA. Also, kind of crazy that the course was capped.

Professor Valeggia gave a lecture that was anti-low income people, basically intimating that they have a lot of children and cant care for them properly in her lecture on life history strategy. As a person on heavy financial aid it was extremely disturbing and alienating for me to hear.
This course can be a little dry in lecture sometimes because occasionally, things will be repeated. Overall, it was very interesting and I learned a lot of things that I didn't know before.

The course provides a good science credit for non-science majors. It is well organized so that students know what is being expected of them. That being said, the material at the end of the course is much more engaging than that of the beginning.

Prof Valeggia begins each class with 5 minutes of meditation, and it became a really important part of my day. It helps refocus everyone for class. I also love how much she loves what she teaches, so lectures are really engaging- she also asks the class questions, which is very helpful.

The material is delivered in a digestible way and the lectures a fairly engaging. The required section was a bit of a waste of time sometimes though and I wish that they had been more guided by the TF as opposed to left up to students to talk.

Strengths: I liked how this course was organized by very clear topics; my favorite units were post-midterm, such as life history theory and male and female reproductive ecology. 

Weaknesses: The exams were definitely stressful to study for given how much material was covered on each. However, I appreciated that the final was not cumulative by topic
Strengths are that it covers a broad range of topics that are interesting. Weaknesses are that the first half of the semester is less engaging and interesting than the second half.
Lectures were interesting. Its was easy to figure out what material to study for exams.
This course is very strong! Overall, it makes scientific topics easy to digest. As a non-STEM person, I learned so much and absolutely loved the material!
The course is engaging and fun. It could benefit from a bit more scientific rigor.

Strengths: This course was stimulating, interesting, and engaging. 

Weaknesses: certain complex processes that were difficult to understand were not fully explained and it was difficult to find accurate explanations of them.
I wish we had linked more of the readings to class discussions.

One strength was how the course was structured--I think the weekly DQs kept me accountable and sections helped clarify more difficult scientific papers. Professor Valeggia's lectures were also extremely helpful in leading us through complicated concepts. One weakness was the denseness of the readings--it was almost impossible for me to do all of the readings before each lecture because they were so long.

The biggest strength is that Professor Valeggia is a phenomenal professor, and at least for Spring 2019, the lectures were recorded and posted online, allowing one to (theoretically) stay in the comfort of one's bed while lecture went on in the relatively-far Luce Hall. The class was extremely well organized: at the beginning of the semester, the a Course Schedule excel file is posted, and it details what classes cover what topics/readings, and what sections cover what readings. Surprisingly, though, the lecture slides themselves weren't organized as much as I'd expect, but this was a minor inconvenience.

I found the course well organized for student learning, and I think the course's greatest strength is its compelling and talented instructor, Professor Valeggia. The course also made me think critically about the disciplines of biology and anthropology, which I really appreciated.

Strengths: The content is, generally speaking, pretty fascinating. Professor Valeggia is a very good lecturer, and the guest lecturers she brought in were great as well (particularly Bribiescas) I felt that I learned a lot  and a lot about things that really affect all of us day-to-day. Exams are in general very fair, and are structured, I think, in a way that does aim for thematic understanding rather than minutiae (do study, and study very thoroughly, but don't stress too much). Many of the readings are very interesting and well-written, so this is a plus as well. 

Weaknesses: Sections were not particularly engaging (it's clear that people don't really do the reading) and not particularly well-led. Obviously, these problems are interrelated. I understand the desire to have non-STEM students learn how to read scientific papers, and I do feel less daunted by these now, but I think the conversations we had in section that were the most interesting were those that came from more journalistic articles; perhaps more of these in the future? It's also my understanding that there were pretty big discrepancies in expectations/grading between TFs, so that might be something to address as well. Sometimes what we needed to know was unclear  we needed to know mechanisms for some processes and not others, for example, and that was often not clear.

I learned more than I thought! The class is mostly all strengths. I only wish that it was clearer which of the claims made in lecture was agreed upon broadly and which were more controversial in the scientific and medical communities, because I have shared some things I learned with friends in STEM who are very skeptical of them, and others that seem to be widely accepted.

A lot of information is covered in this course, but it never feels too overwhelming. When a student finishes this class, they will have a really robust knowledge of evolution and its current implications as well as its history. The structure of the course is incredibly organized, and there is never a question about what is due when. Professor Valeggia and the TA team make the course flow seamlessly, and the once a week sections help students digest the material in lecture in an effective manner. 
I do not have a lot to say in terms of weaknesses. The only thing that comes to mind are the differences in the TAs. For example, we have weekly response questions and some TAs grade more harshly than others. But other than that, honestly nothing.

Professor Valeggia was an engaging and informed professor who clearly wanted to facilitate student learning as much as possible. Lecture was engaging and always taught me something new, informative, and interesting. Because section was always a student presentation on one reading for the entire time, though, it sometimes felt like this aspect of the course didn't help student learning as much as it could have.

All of the material was extremely interesting and Claudia is a great lecturer, caring professor, and warm person.  I would have liked to have assignments that involved more meaningful engagement with the material than just a midterm, final, and reading responses.

Strengths: well-organized, and you knew exactly what was expected of you. 
Weaknesses: sections weren't that great and grading wasn't very standardized.

I rarely found sections useful. I think that having students present wasn't that helpful because I would rather learn from a TF who is experienced in the material, and I think that students (myself included) just fumbled through presentations. 
DQs were also unnecessarily long (would take 3-4 hours in addition to lengthy readings) and often made me more confused about the material than less.
Professor Valeggia is a strength of the course for sure and definitely added to the class. The TFs were helpful as well. The course was straightforward and engaging.

Professor Valeggia is a wonderful professor. She cares a lot about her students and cares about their learning. The readings are interesting. The class was a bit too big though and the Section felt a bit useless.
Better organization, more guidance on work, clearer assignments for discussion questions and deedback
I like that the classes were recorded because it made it very helpful to go back over topics I wasnt sure about when studying.
The professor emphasizes not to memorize or stress but then gives us memorization heavy exams which can be really stressful :(
Clearer expectations

There's not a section to review this, so I'll put it here: I found my section with Kyle to be quite hostile. His volatility and response to students put everyone on edge. At times, our discussions went over articles really well, and others the passive and overt aggression could be overwhelming.

The course gave an introduction to very insightful topics at a level that is approachable, no matter your previous science background. Claudia Valeggia is an amazing professor and is extremely passionate about course topics. She does a very good job of explaining everything.
The course was well taught and covered interesting course material.

Strengths: slides posted, no need to buy textbooks, lectures recorded, topics explained thoroughly and accessible for those outside the field of study, discussion questions were manageable and good, collaborative, meditation
Weaknesses: some topics (ex. ethics) didn't seem to fit well, midterm and final being such a large part of the grade, too many case studies for evolutionary medicine, seemed like a return to high school biology plus fun facts

Strength: I enjoyed this course's weekly homework discussion questions. Answering them always gave me a better understanding of that week's lecture topic and specific readings, and they served as helpful study tools for the midterm and final. I also felt that the material was constantly interesting: we were presented with many specific examples of every topic, most of which were directly applicable to everyday life. So much of what we learned surprised me!

Weakness: Sometimes, section for this course left something to be desired. We would discuss one article each week, presented by a different group of students each time. These presentations were interesting, but if the presenters finished before the 50-minute period was up, I often felt that we weren't encouraged to talk about other, related, topics and therefore ran out of things to say. I wish my TF had come more prepared with ways to effectively use extra section time.

The lectures are too long and I'd find myself writhing in my seat waiting to be free. Some parts of some lectures were interesting, but I thought that much of it was nonessential. The twice-a-week lectures were one hour and fifteen minutes, as opposed to 50 minutes, but still had weekly sections for fifty minutes. I thought this was way too much.

Lectures could also stand to be a little clearer. All of the screenshots and images distract from the main points. The professor did have some slides a the beginning of the lectures outlining some main points, but I would have liked to see more of those throughout.

I really enjoyed the lectures and appreciated that the professor also put them on canvas so that we could follow along. I think the discussion questions helped us get a better sense of what to expect on the mid terms and finals. I really enjoyed that the class started with meditation. The workload was not too much at all. I think it could be improved by going into each of the readings in a bit more depth rather than just choosing one to focus on.
The element of interaction and engagement made for a really interesting and dynamic learning environment.

The lectures were well-organized and Prof. Valeggia was very engaging and spoke passionately about the material. The syllabus for the first half of the semester was more disorganized and there didn't seem to be a clear rationale for the material that was grouped together for the midterm. The second half of the course was much easier to follow. I think section participation and presentations should be worth more, just because so much of the overall grade for the course was determined by the two exams. I thought all the readings supplemented the lectures really well -- especially the more scientific, research-based studies that we read.

Strengths: the subject itself is interesting if you're not that into science. Weaknesses: the lectures were less interesting than I thought they'd be, the TFs are not great so section is pretty uncomfortable and boring, the only grades are basically the final/midterm so be careful.

Weekly reading responses were very constructive. They helped direct my reading each week toward a specific goal, and develop my thoughts on major topics of the week. Lectures were delivered at a good pace, and student participation with the lecturer and each other was an essential component.

strengths: good survey course
weaknesses: wish it went more in depth on certain topics sometimes
Unless you like anthropology, I wouldn't recommend this course. I'm coming from a very biased point of view, but I had a lot of problems with the subject and was frequently bored.

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this class to another student. I really enjoyed Prof. Valeggia's teaching style. On top of that, the material is really engaging. This class is designed as a science credit for non-STEM majors, and I think it lived up to that designation. Students of all majors were able to understand and converse with the course material.
If you are desperate for a final science credit like I was, then this is a great option. However, I did not find it fun or interesting.
Yes! Professor Valeggia is awesome and the class is super fun. It is a great class for fulfilling a science credit and also a good class if you're just looking for something interesting to take.

I would highly recommend this class to anyone looking for a straightforward and enjoyable science credit. As a second semester senior, and a history major, this class was a godsend when I realized that I needed one last SC credit in order to graduate. It's neither extremely difficult nor extremely easy, which I really appreciated. As someone that's had terrible experiences in other Yale science courses, this class was a breath of fresh air. Professor Valeggia is an engaging lecturer who is truly invested in the success of her students. Readings and lectures were fair and did not overwhelm me with information. The midterm was relatively straightforward and I personally thought the questions were fair-- just make sure to attend lecture, take detailed notes, and actually study for the exams!
If you need a science credit. Perfectly fine class but not insightful.

I would not recommend this course to another student unless they are very interested in the material. Students would be better off choosing a class that had more structure and clearer grading standards.
I would definitely recommend this to someone looking for a science credit. I didn't have much scientific background going into this, but found it understandable and interesting!

I would be careful with this one - as it currently stands, it's not a gut (I will explain). Material is generally quite interesting but weekly "discussion questions" are just reading responses, and the readings themselves aren't really necessary besides; section is onerous, as the TAs are supposed to have you discuss but most of the time nobody understands the material (immediately after the preceding lectures) to respond well. Claudia is very nice and has an interesting philosophy regarding learning, which includes meditation before lectures (would recommend), but tests are weighted way too highly and it wasn't very easily to establish a strong synthetic grasp of course material. It seemed to have some trouble navigating the divide between popular science and hard science. All that being said, I learned some really interesting things about humans and human evolution. It's just that the process getting there wasn't always fun.
Yes, great for non-science majors!

As a good easy science for non-STEM majors, sure. And I do not say gut purposefully  you can do well, but you have to study pretty seriously for midterm and final. The course became frustrating at times, but I think overall I learned some theories that are applicable to my social science major/coursework.
As a class at Yale, no. There are much better classes out there to be one of your 36.

I would recommend this course, especially to non-STEM majors seeking science credits. It takes a multidisciplinary approach to a variety of interesting subjects. Also, I learned about a lot of aspects of my daily life that I had never really thought about or studied before. I had planned on just taking this course for the science credit, but it ended up being one of my favorite classes this semester.
if you're looking for an easy and fun science credit - this is one of the best

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone looking for a science credit. The material was interesting and applicable to life, but never too challenging. This course is not a gut, as you have weekly discussion questions and need to study for exams, but this class never felt like a burden in a five course schedule. If you don't like P-Sets, then this course is for you.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Especially as a student with a non-STEM background, this class will make you actually make you enjoy STEM. The topics covered were extremely applicable to daily life, and even as a person who is seemingly averse to anything STEM-related, I found myself being genuinely interested in the material. The class is great for an interesting, not terribly difficult SC credit.
If they want to get an introduction to the content, this is the place to get it.
Yes! Great science credit if you can get in. Workload is low, still end up learning really cool things about people and why we are the way we are.
I would recommend this coure to students who are interested in the sciences, but who want to have time to pursue other academic interests as well.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student because it is not only a good class in general, but it fulfills a science credit for anyone non-stem who would like to take a class that they can then apply to the real world. This class changed the way I thought about sleeping and exercising, and Claudia's five-minute meditations before every class are just the cherry on top. One of my favorite classes here at Yale
Yes! This is an amazing science credit that made me enjoy science

Absolutely! The information is so useful and applicable to many different areas of life. This is one of those classes that I feel I will remember what I learned for future use because it is important and integral to the human experience.
Yes! It introduced me to a wide range of concepts regarding the human organism and humanity in general.
Yes, good intro science course.
Take if you have to otherwise dont
I would recommend this class to any student who is not in a science major, but wants or needs to take a science credit. A lot of the things covered in this class are just good things to know.

I would say that the course is a good, not terribly challenging science credit which, while not entirely intellectually stimulating, is well organized and (especially the end of the course) interesting enough to sustain for a semester.

Yes! There is a fair bit of work -- weekly discussion questions averaging ~300 words that you need to do the readings to answer, plus mandatory section + participation, and a midterm and a final. However, the work is fun and not too difficult, so as long as you're engaged with the course and the material, you'll be totally fine. I didn't find it burdensome at all, and I actually really enjoyed answering the DQs and studying for the exams.

I would recommend this class to anyone looking for a science credit that is actually useful and applicable and that hasn't taken the bio sequences. Anthropology/evolutionary bio classes are ones in which you can learn a lot from without having to have pre-med/a lot of bio background which is nice.

I would definitely recommend this course to any non-science major looking to fulfill a requirement. The material is presented in a way that requires no previous knowledge of anything science related, and the material is both interesting and applicable to life
Yes! Learned some really interesting and incredibly relevant facts about humanity and evolution.
Yes, even if you arent familiar with the subject, it is a very compelling course that makes you want to learn more.
Absolutely! This is the best SC credit out there. Easy to understand and so interesting!
Yes! Fantastic class.
I would recommend this class to someone who wants to learn more about evolution but does not have any scientific background.

Yes! It's a great science gut, because professor Valeggia is really passionate about the topic and will make you generally interested in the material while not demanding obscene amounts of work or intellectual challenge.
Great SC credit. Generally interesting material, good professor and TFs were helpful (I had Kyle)
Yes, the course material was very interesting, and the lecture environment facilitated learning as well.
Yes! Great science credit for humanities/social science majors and super interesting as well.

Yes. However, if you haven't taken AP biology/the equivalent, don't go in assuming it will be easy. You will have to learn lots of that material while everyone around you laughs at the fact that you didn't have that background before you came to Yale. (That said, it is possible.)

I would highly recommend this course, especially to non-STEM people. I am a non-STEM major and I found the material approachable and extremely engaging. What we're learning in class has real-world pertinence.

I would definitely recommend this class to a student trying to fulfill their science credit. You could get destroyed by some Astro "gut", or you could take this instead. Included in the benefits are the following: 5 minute pre-class meditations, weakly reading responses that take about an hour to complete, recorded class lectures (for Spring 2019), a midterm and a final that are the same length, and a newfound appreciation for human evolution. Professor Valeggia is great!

I would definitely recommend this course to other students, especially those with shaky foundations in science. This class made me feel connected to the material and insisted on the relevance of its material.

If you need a science credit, yes. The content is extremely interesting, and so is Professor Valeggia. The course is a little bit disorganized and section feels like a waste of time, generally speaking, but I'm still glad I used a science credit on this class. I learned a lot, and for me the upsides outweighed the downsides. All told, it's a very interesting class that could be organized better, and if you don't need the science credit I would probably think twice but not run away.
Great straightforward class, doesn't get much better for a science requirements. Prof. Valeggia is the best.

YES. Anyone and everyone at Yale should take this class. I particularly recommend it for non-STEM people because it counts as a science credit, but seriously this class will make you love science and think about your class work all week. And I really believe that this class made me a more globally conscious, empathetic person. Professor Valeggia does this in her lecture by focusing on the ethics of science above all else, but she also makes a point to get students in conversation with each other, even during lecture. The reading can seem like a lot, but it is not always necessary (although I always complete them). More than anything, the readings for the weekly section a must.
The grades are heavily determined by two exams, but they were fair and the majority of students did super well on them. Plus, the TAs lead review sessions to help students prepare. Seriously, take this class.

I would recommend this course to a student because, as a non-STEM major, I learned a lot about both key biological concepts as well as biological anthropology as a field. This course always taught me something new and interesting, and I appreciated its focus on marginalized societies (particularly societies and populations that have been marginalized by the field of anthropology in the past) and dismantling past foci on solely western/industrialized societies.

Yes!! Would absolutely recommend this course! I'm a Computer Science major who in her senior spring semester needed a science credit to take, and I'm so happy I took this one. I would also recommend this course to first-years and sophomores because Professor Valeggia is more than willing to help the youngins in finding opportunities in science and land research gigs (though not sure how successfully). Maybe if I were a first-year in this course I would've changed my major.
Yes, although it was more challenging than I thought it would be. I am not a science major, I was taking it more for a credit. But if you are ready to work hard and learn a lot, I do recommend it.
If you're interested in humans definitely
No. Terrible way to do your science credit. The work is erratic with unclear feedback and guidance.
Yes I would, the class was very interesting and the professor made learning enjoyable.

Yes, but it does take some time for non-STEM people to settle in and actually start to enjoy the material because the information could be (just a little) overwhelming at first. Once you get into it, though, youd find the content fairly interesting. Keep in mind that theres a lot of readings to do and by a lot I mean a lot - more than some of my HU and WR classes. It can be unclear what material would be tested on so you would feel kind of pressured to do all the readings carefully. The review sessions were not especially helpful. But the exams are not hard and the workload apart from the readings is pretty light.

Absolutely, great for less STEM-like folks who are still interested in science; everything you learn in this course is immediately applicable to real life either through illustrating context or assisting a better understanding of one's self and body.

Yes! This is an excellent science credit in which you learn to think critically about public health issues we're seeing everywhere. The workload is perfectly designed to be manageable, but you still learn a ton from readings and the discussion questions.
Yes absolutely great science credit
Yes, very fun class. You learn a lot of practical information.
Yes, I would highly recommend! The class itself is not very difficult, but very interesting.
Yes - it covers interesting material and is well taught

I would definitely recommend this course.
The material is extremely interesting and involves real life issues and topics that are relevant to the student experience. I learnt so much about my own body and health and readily passed the information on to my family every week. The class is one of a kind and truly phenomenal.

Yes if they want an introduction to anthropology or a science credit accessible to non-STEM majors. As someone who has taken biology and psychology, much of the material wasn't very new or built off of common sense

Yes! This course was far more fascinating than I expected. If you're curious about what makes humans tick the way we do and why we make the decisions we make, I would absolutely recommend! The workload for this course is also not too heavy, so you will likely never feel too overwhelmed.

There may well be easier ways to get your science credit. Many people seemed to like this class, but I honestly found it quite painful. Take from this what you will.

A good grade is possible if you do well on the tests and consistently on the weekly responses (which are not too bad). If you take the class, I'd advise you not to go to lecture as I did. I realized too late that the lectures are recorded and posted to Canvas, meaning that you could watch them at 2x speed on your own schedule, assuming you have the discipline to do this. I wish I had done that.
Yes, I think this is a great class and the professor is really engaging.
Yes, it was a very interesting course and I have learnt a lot over the semester

Most of the class is made up of non-science majors looking to fulfill their Sc credit, so don't take this course if you're expecting some rigorous science-based discussion in section. It can be quite frustrating when everyone is offering their two cents on epigenetics (for example) when no one really has any foundational understanding of the biological bases. That being said, I think everyone will come away having learned *something.* It's really important to understand female and male reproductive biology and how much of medicine and our understanding of disease ecologies is shaped by culture.
yes! interesting topic, good passionate professor
